Information & Frequently Asked Questions 
Regarding Temporary School Closure


Students and Families

| April 10, 2020 |


 


Derby Public Schools is closing school buildings for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. Our school buildings may be closed, but learning continues! This closure is an effort to help reduce the spread of Coronavirus (COVID-19) and is by executive order from Governor Laura Kelly.

The following document provides some information and answers to address how the school district is moving forward. Please know the following information we are sharing is what we know at this time, these are our current expectations and information is subject to change. Please be prepared for flexibility and grace during these unprecedented times. 


Table of Contents

Athletics
Board Meetings
Bond Projects
Continuous Learning
Curriculum, Grading, and Assessment
District Communications



 

Athletics
Will high school tryouts for fall still occur? Yes, please contact the coach or the district athletic office for more information. 
What are the eligibility requirements for the fall? Eligibility requirements have not changed. If there are questions, please contact the Athletic Director for your school building.
Is there any information on Cheer tryouts? A timeline was created for virtual tryouts. Please contact Coach Schott by emailing kschott@usd260.com.

Board Meetings
Board meetings will continue to occur on the date per the published schedule, however the structure may change.
Where will the board meetings take place if the schools and city building are closed? Remaining board meetings for the 2019-2020 will be held at the Administrative Center 120 E. Washington. We encourage participants to join in virtually via Zoom and viewers to join via YouTube Live. Only select staff members will be physically present during the board meeting, limiting the number of attendees to 10 persons or less per guidelines.
Can patrons still take part in board meetings and how does this work? Patrons wishing to speak before the board during the public comment agenda item can email the board clerk at lhoyt@usd260.com or submit a comment in writing by clicking here. Written comments or requests to speak should be submitted before Monday afternoon (12:00PM) prior to the board meeting. Submitted written comments will be summarized by the board president during the comments section with a copy provided to the entire board after the meeting. Derby Public Schools will follow health guidelines and have no more than 10 people in the physical board meeting room at a time.

Bond Projects
Is construction going to continue? At this time construction is considered an essential activity under the guidance provided by the State of Kansas. Construction of all Bond projects is continuing at this time.
Is the bond timeline going to be impacted? At this time there have been no schedule impacts.

Continuous Learning
Learning continues at Derby Public Schools. The intention of the framework is to define how we will maximize our educational resources in this unprecedented time.
How is my child going to continue to learn? Please read more information about the Derby Learning Task Force Recommendations and how learning will continue with the Derby Continuous Learning Implementation Framework. 
How do I set my student(s) up for success while participating in continuous learning? Suggestions include: Set up a schedule and consistent workspace for your child to participate in lessons and/or complete school work. Allow for flexibility, and breaks when needed, and be on hand to assist. Look over your student’s work and provide support or feedback when needed. 
Will the district be taking attendance? Please see the District Continuous Learning Framework, page 5, “Online attendance monitoring”
What if we don’t have the internet? Please see the District Continuous Learning Framework, page 5. In addition we’ve had some generous donations which have made funds available for families. Please contact your building principal for more information.
My child is on an IEP, how is continuous learning going to abide by the IEP? Please visit the Special Services Clarification Guide.
What does this mean for state testing? State testing is canceled.
What about grades and how will students be graded? Students will be graded based on an average of their grades from Quarter 1-3. Secondary students who have semester classes will have grades from Quarter 3. If the student does exceptionally well there is an opportunity for the student’s grade to improve.
Clarification of services at HeartSpring and Tri City Day School? Any student that is currently receiving special education services at a separate location should have been contacted by that agency/service providers for educational services for our students as this has been verified by Special Services. If a parent has a concern or needs assistance, we are encouraging them to be in contact with their child’s teacher. If further assistance is needed, please email Luan Sparks at lsparks@usd260.com
Can we access books or other items that were left at school? If your student missed the opportunity to pick up books or other items from school an additional opportunity to pick up all items will be provided in the future. If there are medications or other essential items needed, please email your school principal.
How can my student connect with their teacher? Students can connect with their teacher through email during their office hours.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":5855,"s":"
Curriculum, Grading, and Assessment
Will teachers cover the same amount of work that they would normally during 4th quarter? No, teachers will offer shorter lessons and assignments that will cover the essential learning students need from 4th quarter coursework.
How does a student’s workload with continuous learning compare to their normal workload? The amount of work should be less and will vary by subject and grade level. 
How will teachers get my student ready for next year? Teachers will provide instruction through packets, online activities or independently completed online assignment options for students. Students who qualify needing additional support will be provided small group lessons from special education, ELL, reading specialists or math interventionists. 
What will grading look like? Grading will look different. Elementary and Middle schools will provide grades based upon the average of the students’ scores for the first three quarters and work completion during quarter four. High school grades will be based upon the 3rd quarter grade and the student's 4th quarter work completion. Each student’s grade should remain the same unless the student shows a dramatic increase in completion and quality of school work. 
Will there be testing? State assessments, end of the year district tests, and finals will not be administered during Spring of 2020.

District Communications
Regular district newsletters such as the e-news (families, once a month September-May) will continue as normal. Board of Education meeting summaries will also continue as normal and be e-mailed to staff the day after a BOE meeting. They are also posted HERE. Google Calendars, websites and social media pages should be cleared of any pre-scheduled events. 
Will I Make a Difference Awards still continue? The I Make a Difference Awards (IMAD) will not continue this year. We will resume in September. We will hold over any nominations we currently have and will continue to accept nominations. 
Will Skylerts still be going out to families? The automated attendance and food service notifications have been turned off for all schools for the remainder of the year.

Latchkey and Summer Programs
Will Latchkey still occur? No, Latchkey is canceled as well.
Will Summer Latchkey take place? At this time, no decision has been made.
Will Latchkey employees be paid? Yes, Latchkey employees will be paid through the end of the school year.

Meals for Students
Derby Public Schools is providing free pre-packaged meals by curbside pickup for any child ages 1-18 while schools are closed. There is no income requirement, address stipulations, or registration required. View meal sites HERE. Meal service may close without notice in the event of inclement weather such as steady rain, lightning, tornado watch, etc.
When are you handing out meals? We will be providing curbside pickup Monday through Friday from 11:30AM-1:00PM based on the 2019-2020 school year calendar. If school is not in session on the calendar, meals will not be served that day. See calendar HERE. 
What are the locations for the meal service?
Central Kitchen 610 E. Market, Derby
Oaklawn Elementary, 5000 S. Clifton Avenue, Wichita
Wineteer Elementary, 8801 E. Ent, Wichita 
(please note the McConnell AFB housing gate will be open from 12:00-1:00PM)
Does my child have to be present with me to get a meal? Children between 1 and 18 (including students who are older than 18 and enrolled in USD 260 programs) will be served lunch but must be present the first time to receive a meal. After your first visit, you will receive a number to display on the dashboard of your vehicle. Present this number on your dashboard for future visits and your child does not need to be present for you to pick up a meal for them.
Do they have to be students/enrolled in the school district to get a meal? No, this meal service is open to all children ages 1 through 18. Students older than 18 who are enrolled in a district program may also receive a meal.
Can adults receive meals? At this time, no.
My child has an allergy, are there meal modifications? We are offering meal substitutions, including celiac disease, gluten intolerance and peanut allergies. Please let us know your child’s name, which location for meal service, and which days they will be picking up a meal by contacting the Food Service Supervisor, Martha Lawson at (316) 788-8419 or mlawson@usd260.com.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":10332,"s":"
Operations
Are buildings being monitored? Select district staff are monitoring buildings on a daily basis to make sure the building is secure and monitor mechanical systems or plumbing concerns that may arise.

Out of District / In District Transfers
When will the transfer request forms be available? The transfer request forms opened April 1 virtually.

Professional Leave, Out of State Travel, Activity Trips
All student and staff travel and professional development trips (in state, out of state, as well as guest speakers coming to the district) are canceled. The Finance Department will handle all cancellations.
Will I get money back for a district trip that I paid for? Please let your building/department secretary know if you’ve paid for any district travel. We will handle this on a case by case basis.

Records Requests
How will the district handle KORA requests and Freedom of Information inquiries? Please send records requests to Dr. Andy Koenigs at akoenigs@usd260.com or call the Human Resource Department at 788-8415.
Will the district still be able to provide student transcripts or employment verifications? Yes, requests can be made via phone, email or fax at this time. Student transcript requests should be emailed to Kelly Herring at kherring@usd260.com and employment verifications should be emailed to Jenny Ramsey at jramsey@usd260.com. 

School and District Events
At this time, all district and school events are canceled or on hold. This includes, but is not limited to:
Graduation scheduled for May 10 at Koch Arena
Volunteer Movie Matinee scheduled for April 18, 2020 at the Derby Plaza Theaters
Staff Appreciation Event scheduled for May 5, 2020 at the Botanica Gardens
Kindergarten Round Up
Pleasantview Open House scheduled for Saturday, May 2 2-5PM
Elementary Open House for students and families scheduled for Thursday, May 7, 5:30-7:30PM
Can PTOs provide outreach to students/staff?
Yes, PTOs should work with the building principal regarding any initiatives and must follow CDC, KDHE, and local health department guidelines.

Students
Can I pick up my student’s personal belongings (contents from lockers or cubbies)? Not at this time. We hope that when the guidance is lifted, we will be able to have students retrieve their personal belongings.
Can I pick up my student’s medication from their school? Medication pick up occurred Wednesday, March 25-Thursday, March 26. Medication that was not picked up on those dates will continue to be locked up at the student’s school. If it is imperative for a parent to pick up medication, parents are to contact their building principal. 
What about McKinney-Vento students? Derby Public Schools will continue to evaluate and qualify students for services under the McKinney-Vento Act. At this time, services may be limited due to the pandemic situation. Social Workers and Counselors are encouraged to be in contact with students and families to check in and make community resources available as needed, such as meals being offered by the school, etc. Please continue to send student names to Doylene Elston at delston@usd260.com for appropriate follow up. 
Will I need to return school items that are checked out such as library books or other instructional items? Yes, a future date will be established for students to pick up classroom materials and turn in checked out items. 
What if I have a senior who is graduating in May and credits needed? The board has approved changing the graduation requirement for the 2019-2020 school year only. The Graduation requirements are changed from 25 credit hours to 21 credit hours. It is important to note that the core state requirements for graduation still must be met. This is only applicable to the class of 2020. 
What are the plans for the graduation ceremony? At this time, the graduation ceremony for May 10 is canceled. The high school administration sent out a survey asking families for feedback of what type of recognition students would want to see. The district will be working on future plans to honor our seniors. 
Where do I go for more information on AP Courses? Please find more information here: https://apcentral.collegeboard.org/about-ap/news-changes/coronavirus-update
Will the college board still administer AP Exams? Yes. They will be coming up with a solution to have students test at home, depending on the situation in May.
Are there resources available for virtual learning? The College Board is developing additional YouTube videos and tools. 
Can I get a refund on my student’s lunch account balance? Normally we only allow refunds on balances when a student withdraws. Under these conditions, if a parent contacts the building we are allowing a refund at this time.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":15117,"s":"
Student Expectations
What are students being asked to do? Students are asked to continue learning through the family’s choice of paper packet, online lessons, and materials or assignments shared with families.
How much daily work is my student going to be asked to do? The amount of daily work will vary by grade level, subject area and teacher. General times are listed below. Additional personalized support may be added based upon student’s needs. 
Grades K-1: 15 ELA, 15 Math, 15 Science/Social Studies
Grades 2-3: 20 ELA, 20 Math, 20 Science/Social Studies
Grades 4-5: 30 ELA, 30 Math, 30 Science/Social Studies
Grades 6-8 (middle school): 30 minutes ELA, 30 minutes Math, 30 minutes Social Studies30 minutes Science,60 minutes Electives/Skills/Interventionists
Grades 9-12 (high school): 30 minutes per teacher 
What if my student becomes ill and isn’t able to complete the work? Student work will not be counted if they become ill or are unable to complete the work. Please communicate with your child’s school based upon your circumstances.
Is school taking attendance? Traditional attendance is not being taken and there is not a penalty for not participating.

Student Support
How will my student get help from their teacher(s) and what will communication look like? Each teacher will have designated flexible “Office Hours” where your student can make an appointment or drop in on determined times. These office visits are virtual through email or chat requests. 
How will the district support Social Emotional Needs and Support? Building social workers and/or counselors are available for collaboration, consultation, guidance, and resources for supporting social emotional needs. 
What are Check-Ins and how will that look? Teachers will check-in with students at the elementary level daily for lessons. Secondary students will check in with their teachers online during homeroom twice a week. 
How does my student access their Special Education services? All parents should have been contacted by their child’s special education teacher or provider for related services. The type of services and methods of delivery will vary according to the child’s Individual Education Plan (IEP). All students that are receiving special services will have a Prior Written Notice (PWN) and Individual Continuous Learning Plan (ICLP) sent to the parents that will outline what all services will look like through the time that school is not in session. The primary focus will be on IEP goals. Services are available via online, resource links online, paper-pencil, and consultative. No services are provided onsite or in a parent’s home at this time. 
My student does not have an IEP but receives additional supports (ESOL, Reading Specialists, Tiered Intervention, etc), will those continue? Yes, small group instruction and academic support provided by ELL, Reading Specialists, Math Interventionists, Math Para and AmeriCorps tutoring will continue to be offered to support students. ELL support for language learners will be provided either during class time or after in a small group setting. The additional academic support from reading specialists, math interventionists, math paraprofessionals and AmeriCorps members will be scheduled with each student’s family as an optional support. Families should have been contacted for additional supports, if you have not, please contact your building principal.
Will additional summer school opportunities be provided for students who need or want supplemental instruction? Summer school opportunities will be determined and communicated in May 2020. We are closely monitoring the spread of COVID-19 and will provide updates as they become available. Students that may qualify for Extended School Year (ESY) will continue to have services; although, it may continue online if the current home orders are still in place. 


DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":19215,"s":"What if students don’t have a device? The district deployed district devices the week of March 23-27 to all students. If you did not receive one, please contact your building principal.
Do students/families have tech support? Yes, tech support will be M-F from 7:30AM-7:00PM. We understand that our current technology team is stretched thin with the continuous learning support needed for parents, staff and students. In response to task force concerns about technology assistance, we have developed and trained a Tech Triage Team to provide an additional layer of assistance for families and decrease the odds of students waiting for technology assistance and the back-up of help tickets. 
If a student, family member or staff member needs assistance please complete this google form and you will be contacted promptly to provide support. 
What do I do if my student’s device is damaged and it needs to be repaired. More information will be posted on our Technology website (linked above).
Do student devices have filtering? Yes, the district has internet security and content filtering managed through two systems active on devices whether on school property or on any other internet connection, public or private. 

Resources
State Waiver for Hours
KDHE High Risk Areas
Employee Assistance Program New website. District Login Code is USD 260.
